neighbors.name: Arthur E. Graulich
neighbors.claims: Arthur E. Graulich was a lifelong farmer and local official who passed away in February 2024 at age 94 [Mereness-Putnam Funeral Home](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/m/obituaries/Arthur-Graulich/). He served 18 years as Town of Carlisle Supervisor and chaired the Schoharie County Board of Supervisors, while also serving on town and county planning boards and the county agriculture committee [Mereness-Putnam Funeral Home](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/m/obituaries/Arthur-Graulich/). His family farm, Argus Acres, has operated in Schoharie County since 1948, reflecting his deep roots in local agriculture [Mereness-Putnam Funeral Home](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/m/obituaries/Arthur-Graulich/).
neighbors.influence_justification: County board ex-chair; longtime farm advocate

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via his family or trusted farm community contacts, emphasizing respect for his farm legacy and local oversight.

neighbors.name: Francis Johnson
neighbors.claims: Francis Johnson is a Cobleskill-area landowner, but little publicly available information exists about him or his activities [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Francis-Johnson/NY). No references to Johnson were found in local meeting records or media, suggesting he has not taken any visible role in community affairs [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach personally via a farming community connection, emphasizing listening to any land use or property concerns.

neighbors.name: Carl Ilowiecki
neighbors.claims: Carl Ilowiecki owns a rural parcel in the Cobleskill area and maintains a very low public profile [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Carl-Ilowiecki/NY). No public records or news mentions show Ilowiecki engaging in local civic matters or commenting on development issues [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

neighbors.name: Harry Laux

neighbors.name: Mark Pinheiro
neighbors.claims: Mark Pinheiro owns a parcel in the Cobleskill area but has no public profile or known community involvement [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Mark-Pinheiro/NY). There are no public indications of Pinheiro’s views on local development, and his name does not appear in any local civic records or news reports [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a straightforward, informative approach (e.g., a personal visit) to address any questions he may have about noise, traffic, or property impacts.

neighbors.name: Dorothy Gerdes
neighbors.claims: Dorothy Gerdes appears to be a private landowner in Cobleskill, with no mention of her in local meeting minutes or news archives as of the latest search [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml). No public statements or civic positions by Gerdes were found to indicate any involvement in community development issues [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Introduce the project to her in a respectful, personal way via a trusted local contact or neighbor. Emphasize listening to any concerns she may have and assure her that her property and peace will be respected.

neighbors.name: Paul Zabinski
neighbors.claims: Paul Zabinski has family ties to Albany County: a 2010 obituary for his father (from Menands, NY) listed Paul (and his wife Lori) as residents of Menands, indicating he was not originally a Cobleskill local [Albany Times Union](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/timesunion-albany/name/john-zabinski-obituary?id=4958651). No record of Zabinski’s participation in Cobleskill-area civic activities or public commentary on development was found in available public documents [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Since he appears to live outside the area, reach out via formal letter or phone to explain the project and address any concerns. Provide clear information on how the development might affect (or not affect) his property to engage him constructively.

neighbors.name: Julian G Housel
neighbors.claims: Public directory records list Julian G. Housel, age 82, as residing in Schenectady, NY, rather than in Schoharie County [Veripages](https://veripages.com/name/Julian/Housel/). His name also appeared in a Schenectady property transaction (a 2010 sale on Avenue A), reinforcing that his primary connections are outside Cobleskill [Times Union](https://www.timesunion.com/living/article/Deeds-Deals-955449.php). No local government or civic records name Julian Housel in any development discussions or community roles in Cobleskill [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Communicate with Mr. Housel via mail or a family representative due to his age and non-local residence. Ensure he receives project information in a clear, accessible format and invite him to discuss any questions or concerns by phone.

neighbors.name: Robert Ilowiecki
neighbors.claims: Robert Ilowiecki’s late parents moved the family to rural Schoharie County (Carlisle, near Cobleskill) in the mid-1970s from Long Island, but Robert himself has been identified as living in Troy, NY in recent years [Albany Times Union](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/timesunion-albany/name/joan-ilowiecki-obituary?id=5031954). He appears to be an absentee landowner with no evident involvement in local boards or public comments on development matters in Cobleskill [Albany Times Union](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/timesunion-albany/name/joan-ilowiecki-obituary?id=5031954). No local meeting minutes or news reports were found that mention him taking any stance on community projects [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out to Mr. Ilowiecki through a written notice or email sent to his Troy address, given he isn’t on-site locally. Provide clear details about the development and an invitation to discuss, acknowledging his family’s historical ties to the area to build rapport.

neighbors.name: Laurell L Tyler
neighbors.claims: No public information could be found regarding Laurell L. Tyler’s background or community involvement. A search of local records and news did not yield any references to Tyler in civic roles or statements on development issues [Schoharie County Public Documents](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/SchoCo/BoardMinutesIndex.xhtml). Based on available data, Tyler appears to be a private local resident with no noted public profile or known stance on the proposed development.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Laurell Tyler in a neighborly manner – for example, via a casual in-person visit or community meeting invitation – to open lines of communication. Without any known position, listening to her questions and priorities will be key to engagement.

neighbors.claims: No substantial information on Joseph Zeh was found in public records or local media, suggesting he keeps a very low profile ([www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/VillCob/index.xhtml#:~:text=No%20,zeh)). neighbors.name: Gerald J. Toscano
neighbors.claims: Gerald J. Toscano, now in his early 60s, relocated from New Jersey and began listing a Cobleskill address (Little York Road) around 2012 ([besthistorysites.net](https://besthistorysites.net/name/gerald-toscano#:~:text=Gerald%20J%20Toscano%20is%20sixty,1348)) ([besthistorysites.net](https://besthistorysites.net/name/gerald-toscano#:~:text=39%20Mayer%20Dr%2C%20Clifton%2C%20NJ%2C,current%20address)). He has only recently become a full-time resident, and his name does not appear in local government records, indicating no notable community involvement to date ([www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/VillCob/index.xhtml#:~:text=No%20,toscano)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a neighborly approach – perhaps via a friendly long-time resident – to welcome him and reassure that the project will respect the area’s rural character.

neighbors.name: Allan L. Tillapaugh
neighbors.claims: Allan L. Tillapaugh belongs to a fourth-generation dairy farming family in Schoharie County ([www.nysenate.gov](https://www.nysenate.gov/newsroom/in-the-news/2009/james-l-seward/seward-speaks-out-dairy-farmers#:~:text=Susan%20Tillapaugh%20of%20Carlisle%2C%20married,are%20near%20the%20tipping%20point)). His family operates a local dairy business (CDS Tillapaugh LLC) in Cobleskill, focused on dairy cattle and milk production ([naicslist.com](https://naicslist.com/company-profile/cds-tillapaugh-llc-carlisle-ny-12031#:~:text=New%20York%20Company%20in%20the,Cattle%20and%20Milk%20Production%20Sector)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through agricultural community channels – for example, have a fellow farmer or farm bureau member start the conversation – and highlight how the development can align with and even support long-term farm viability.

Hicks; his name does not surface in local news or public meeting archives ([www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov](https://www2.schohariecounty-ny.gov/EdocWebApp/faces/VillCob/index.xhtml#:~:text=No%20,hicks)). Trucking, LLC based in Cobleskill ([www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/obituaries/william-ward-jr#:~:text=Carlisle,which%20he%20operated%20several%20years)) ([www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/obituaries/william-ward-jr#:~:text=School,race%20cars%20and%20most%20recently)). approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with Mr. Ward’s family or estate executor in a respectful manner. Emphasize understanding their plans for the property and explain how the project could align with the family’s interests now that Mr. Ward is deceased.

neighbors.name: Raymond D. Briggs
neighbors.claims: Raymond D. Briggs was born in 1924 on a family farm in Carlisle and was a lifelong Schoharie County resident ([www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/obituaries/raymond-briggs#:~:text=Carlisle,area%20resident%20and%20received%20his)). He served as the Town of Carlisle’s historian and was active in local heritage circles, reflecting community involvement until his death in 2011 ([www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/obituaries/raymond-briggs#:~:text=Carlisle%20Town%20Historian%20and%20was,Bernard%29%20Braun)) ([www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com](https://www.merenessputnamfuneralhome.com/obituaries/raymond-briggs#:~:text=Carlisle,area%20resident%20and%20received%20his)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with his family (e.g., his local sons) when addressing this property. Showing respect for the family’s legacy and the historical significance of their land will help build goodwill.

Santoro has no notable public presence in Cobleskill’s civic affairs ([www.cobleskilltimesjournal.com](https://www.cobleskilltimesjournal.com/index.asp?type=Social#:~:text=Cobleskill%20Times,floats%2C%20followed%20by%20a%20short)). DeGeorge’s property appears to be a multi-generational farm; several DeGeorge family members (ages spanning late 30s to late 60s) reside there, with one listed as a farmer by occupation ([hudwayglass.com](https://hudwayglass.com/HIGHWAY%2BROUTE%2B20%2C%2BDorloo%2BNY#:~:text=David%20L%20Degeorge%20%20,Job%3A%20Craftsman%2FBlue%20Collar)). neighbors.claims: Frank A. Johnson is identified as a landowner residing in Cobleskill, Schoharie County [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Frank-A-Johnson/Cobleskill-NY). There is no indication from public records that Johnson has taken any active stance or made statements regarding local development plans [Google Search](https://www.google.com/search?q=Frank+A+Johnson+Cobleskill).

neighbors.name: Rock District Solar LLC
neighbors.claims: In line with New York's Clean Energy Standard (targeting 70% renewable electricity by 2030), Greenbacker Renewable Energy Company is proposing the 20 MW Rock District Solar project in Schoharie County, New York [Cypress Creek Renewables — company website, accessed 2025-12-20; "Greenbacker Renewable Energy Company is proposing the construction of 'Rock District Solar.' The proposed Facility is a 20 megawatt (MW) photovoltaic (PV) solar energy generating project located within the Towns of Carlisle and Seward, Schoharie County, New York."](https://ccrenew.com/rock-district/). The project's site spans roughly 316 acres of rural land (with about 125 acres used for solar infrastructure) and will interconnect via an adjacent 69 kV transmission line [Cypress Creek Renewables — company website, accessed 2025-12-20; "total approximately 316 acres, of which approximately 125 acres will be occupied by Facility infrastructure ... 69 kilovolt (kV) transmission line."](https://ccrenew.com/rock-district/). A coordinated environmental review (SEQRA) found no significant impacts, and the project's Section 94-c permit application is under state review by the Office of Renewable Energy Siting [Cypress Creek Renewables — company website, accessed 2025-12-20; "no significant adverse environmental impacts ... reviewed by ORES"](https://ccrenew.com/rock-district/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Backed by a well-funded renewable energy firm (Greenbacker); pursuing a 20 MW solar project under state review; minimal local history or community ties.

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate directly with the project's sponsor (Greenbacker Renewable Energy) to address any mutual concerns. Emphasize shared renewable goals and ensure your plans won't hinder their solar farm; explore potential collaboration on grid interconnection or community outreach.

overview_summary: For all five profiled neighbors, no clear public stance on development or clean energy could be identified (0 support, 0 oppose, 5 unknown). Only one neighbor – an influential former local official – stands out with high community influence; the rest appear to have low profiles and minimal sway in local affairs. None of the five profiled neighbors have a clearly documented stance regarding development or clean energy – in fact, 0 are on record supporting or opposing the project, with all five classified as "unknown" in stance. Their community influence also appears limited; none hold high-profile positions locally, and most have no public civic roles or leadership credentials, suggesting they are low-influence neighbors overall. All five adjacent landowners have no publicly documented stance on development or clean energy – none have made clear statements of support or opposition. Most lack formal community roles; only one (Tillapaugh) is part of a prominent multi-generation farm family, indicating some community influence, while the rest appear to have low public profiles. None of these five neighboring landowners have a documented stance for or against development, as no public statements or actions could be found. Most appear to be low-profile residents with no formal community roles; one was a local business owner but is now deceased. Influence in the community is limited across the group, with all but one rated low and no high-influence neighbors identified. All five neighbors have an undetermined stance, with none having made public statements for or against the development. Likewise, none are high-profile community figures; most keep low profiles as private landowners (one was a town historian in the past), so overall community influence is low. All four profiled neighbors are private residents with no documented stance on local development (each is classified as "unknown" stance). None hold any public office or prominent community role; influence levels are low across the board with no high-influence neighbors identified. Rock District Solar LLC appears to be a special-purpose entity backed by Greenbacker Renewable Energy, aimed at constructing a 20 MW solar farm in Schoharie County. This profile suggests a commercial renewable energy developer (not a local resident or grassroots group). As a neighbor, they are likely focused on advancing their state-permitted solar project; they could potentially align with other renewable initiatives, but might also compete for grid connection capacity or similar resources.
